instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage 18volt on pp3v42
threads.message:
Hi all,

so got this puppy in from a repair shop they seem to have cleaned it.
wel around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> there was some water.
after replacing the ic and caps around it that had damage,
nice stable pp3v42

but nothing for the rest.
no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
no vcore
no S4 lines
psirom looks good

could the 18volt on pp3v42 killed the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage 18volt on pp3v42
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage 18volt on pp3v42
threads.message:
Yes starts green turns orange
ppbus-g3h 12,60v
smc-lid 3,3volt (memory not at shop atm)
smc-reset-l present 3,3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage 18volt on pp3v42
threads.message: Check the usual, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> termination resistors/traces. Clock chip area, 3V to RTC. If there really was 18V on 3V42 the SMC would be dead, but it seems fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage 18volt on pp3v42
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> ternimation resistors measure good and traces look good also the coper points are pretty and nice round

<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> 32.68mhz on osciliscope but jumping up and down from 32.86mhz to 32.89mhz (0.395volt i dont know if this is even needed please tell me if it is i think the mhz is the needed)

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.392volt

<SIGNAL>SPI_ROM</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.327v
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO0_MOSI</SIGNAL> 3.327v
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO1_MISO</SIGNAL> 3.327v
SPI MLBROM CS L 3.327v
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO2_WP_L</SIGNAL> 3.327v
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO3_HOLD_L</SIGNAL> 3.327v

threads.message: Check for power cycling on 5V rails. Check all rails for shorts.

threads.message: I bet this will power on just fine with a good battery installed. What is PPBUS voltage on just the battery? Is it even charging?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage 18volt on pp3v42
threads.message:
yes it does Duke, turns on with known good battery.

it also charges, booted to os and checked went up from 70% to 100% no issues.

charger connected <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.85V

wont turn on with only charger <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.59v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage 18volt on pp3v42
threads.message:
oke, this is fun.

when I insert a SSD  (know working)
it boots fine, fan spins no issues charges etc.

when I insert the original SSD.
it wont boot unless I press the power button, the SSD is not recognized.
no fan spin.

not working SSD
when I then measure
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_SSD_P</SIGNAL> 0.245 diode
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_SSD_N</SIGNAL> 0.245 diode

Working SSD
when I measure
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_SSD_P</SIGNAL> 0.030 diode
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_SSD_N</SIGNAL> 0.030 diode

this is the only difference I could find.

hints are welkom
